summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against a Macon, Georgia woman for her role in the death of her three-year-old son.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Atlanta, alleges that Latonya Sanders, a resident of Warner Robins, Georgia, provided false testimony to the trial court regarding the circumstances surrounding the interviews with Reid and her mother.  According to the complaint, Reid told her mother that she had found a knot on her head when she fell on the back porch of her home on May 22, 2013, the day Jakarie Reid was transported to the hospital from a hospital.  She also allegedly told Herndon that she spanked her son for playing with a jump rope the day before, and that she did not spank him.  In addition, the complaint alleges that Reid and Sanders were out of money and had been pawning personal items to come up with cash in order to pay rent and activate utility service to the house.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, Reid was not in custody when she was interviewed by the detective bureau and had become especially “tired of” potty-training her two young children.  Reid also alleges that her mother had told her not to pee on her son, telling her that he would "not do that."  The complaint further alleges that, while Reid was in custody, she had confronted her mother about her son’s behavior and told her that she would “not spank her son.”  In a parallel action, the U. S. Attorney‘s Office for New Jersey today announced that it has obtained a court order halting the unsealing of the criminal case against Reid.  On May 23, 2018, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action against Reid, charging her with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and with aiding and abetting her violations of Section 17(a)(1) and (3) of Exchange Act Section 13(a) and Rule 17(b)(5) thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint against her, Reid consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins her from future violations of the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, orders her to pay a civil penalty of $1,000, and requires her to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation of the matter.  Additionally, Reid agreed to a conduct-based injunction prohibiting her from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any security
